G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this modification action pursuant to G.L. c. 209B, § 2 as the children reside in Massachusetts and the original custody order was issued by this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: Venue is proper in Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28A because both parties reside in Bristol County, and the present action concerns the interests of the minor children who reside in the Commonwealth.

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody order may be modified upon demonstration of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a showing that modification serves the best interests of the children.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..proposition: Case law has consistently held that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters. See **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**; **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody determinations “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and interprets the governing statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Although the case focuses on relocation, it repeatedly frames the analysis around the child’s best interests as the controlling standard in custody-related decisions, so it directly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child….”

**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Case law has consistently held that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody matters. See **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**; **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman repeatedly frames the removal and custody-modification question in terms of the children’s best interests and treats that standard as controlling. The court interprets the statutory "upon cause shown" language in G. L. c. 208, § 30, to mean that removal must be in the children’s best interests and then reviews the trial judge’s decision solely under that standard. This directly affirms that the best interests of the child are paramount in custody-related matters such as relocation.
**Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… a minor child… shall not… be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.proposition: The Court considers, inter alia, the emotional and developmental needs of the child, the capacity of each parent to act in the child’s best interests, and the ability of the parents to cooperate.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard and lists factors that a judge may weigh in custody determinations, including stability, sibling relationships, and whether a parent seeks to undermine the child’s relationship with the other parent. In applying that standard, the court focuses heavily on the child’s emotional and developmental needs, each parent’s capacity to put the child’s needs first, and the parents’ willingness (or refusal) to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent. This aligns with the proposition that the court considers emotional and developmental needs, parental capacity to act in the child’s best interests, and the ability of parents to cooperate.
**Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’….’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

**Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court considers, inter alia, the emotional and developmental needs of the child, the capacity of each parent to act in the child’s best interests, and the ability of the parents to cooperate.
**Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the legal standard for modification of custody (need for a relevant change in circumstances and best interests generally) and on error in changing custody without such findings. Although the court briefly mentions the guardian ad litem’s hope that joint legal custody would encourage communication and notes the child’s adjustment to schools and relationships, the Appeals Court does not itself articulate a standard requiring consideration of emotional/developmental needs, each parent’s capacity to act in the child’s best interests, or the parents’ ability to cooperate. Those factors are not set out as part of the governing legal test here, so the case does not affirm the specific proposition claimed.
**Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In sum, there is nothing in the record that shows any relevant change in circumstances that would justify the transfer of custody ordered in this case. The fact that the mother did not seek permission to remove the child from the Commonwealth does not give the judge discretion to order a change in custody solely because of the failure to obtain consent. … At the hearing the judge must consider the factors outlined in Hale v. Hale, at 815-819, in making the decision on the complaint.”

**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Persistent violations of the terms of a custody agreement and behavior that undermines a child’s relationship with the other parent may justify modification. See **Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)**; **Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)**.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The case is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focused on whether a custodial parent may relocate children out of state under the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test. It does discuss the mother’s alleged efforts to interfere with the father’s relationship, but only as one factor in evaluating motive for removal, not as a basis to modify custody because of persistent violations or undermining conduct. The opinion does not hold that such conduct justifies modification of custody, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
**Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In evaluating the mother’s proposed move, the judge gave weight to the possibility that the move was inspired, at least in part, by the mother’s desire to separate the children from the father. In this regard, the judge found that the mother kept the father uninformed on various subjects and did not encourage the children to communicate with him. The judge also quoted the opinion of the guardian ad litem that ‘Mother’s desire to move is motivated by a desire to interfere with the relationship between [the two boys] and their father.’”

**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Persistent violations of the terms of a custody agreement and behavior that undermines a child’s relationship with the other parent may justify modification. See **Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)**; **Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)**.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion does not deal with persistent violations of a custody agreement or conduct undermining the child’s relationship with the other parent as a basis for modification. Instead, the court reverses a change of custody, holding there was no material and substantial change in circumstances beyond the mother’s relocation, and it emphasizes that relocation alone cannot justify a custody modification. Nothing in the reasoning suggests that ongoing noncompliance or alienating behavior justified the (reversed) modification, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
**Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… The judgment modifying custody must be reversed.”

**Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. **Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bak v. Bak is a first‑instance custody determination in the divorce, not a modification of a prior custody order. The court evaluates best interests, jurisdiction, and forum issues, but nowhere discusses a ‘pattern of conduct’ causing emotional harm as a material change in circumstances warranting reconsideration of an existing custody arrangement. The case therefore does not address, much less establish, the modification standard described in the proposition.
**Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Anthony maintains that the grant of custody of Rosemary and Tony to Sonja was wrong. A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the children. … Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. … On balance, however, the judge’s decision… is not plainly wrong.”

**Anderson v. Anderson, 407 Mass. 251 (1.support_reasoning: The Anderson opinion deals with paternity, claim preclusion, Rule 60(b) relief from judgment, and enforcement of child support, not custody or modification of custody based on emotional harm to children. Nowhere does the court discuss a material change in circumstances standard in the custody context or recognize a pattern of conduct causing emotional harm as grounds to reconsider custody. Thus, citing Anderson for that custody-related proposition misstates its holding and subject matter.
**Anderson v.
